div1.head: Jim to Mlle. Marcelle Guerin July 18th 1915
div1.p: I have just received your letter of the 15th telling me about Carb’s leaving and Rockwell’s saunter with you. I envy them so much seeing you, but I do not envy Carb for he is leaving, and in leaving loses the chance for continuing in the finest work it will ever be his fortune to see again.
I’ll bet your Frenchman just over from America is going to be a spy for the government. Isn’t that so? That makes two now. You ought to have some good inside information about the enemy.

The only good news I have is that Ambulance No. 1 is to be sent to the town below us and No 3, that is there, brought up. The Medicine Chef complained it was too dangerous and asked to be moved back. Incidentally he waited until he got his Croix de Guerre before he asked for the move. The darned old slobs. I’m glad the change has been made. Another advantage lies in the fact that No. 3 is new at the front and we can get them to hustle from the start as we’re older around here than they are. I sent a letter in by Barclay who is leaving for America so I guess you have it by now. It seems years since I’ve heard any news of Paul. I’m anxious to hear what his plans are, for I am making application for a leave in September to go in and see you all and while I know you will be at
the same old post I’m not sure of Paul. My friend Betty Baldwin, I am sorry to hear, is going to leave for a two months’ trip to the States, and will be away when I get to Paris. She’s a peach. I wish you knew her. Do you know Miss Lines [sp?] at the Ambulance? She’s a friend of hers.

There is very little new up here. We are now mostly interested in what’s going on in other secteurs and on the other fronts. I am not at all alarmed about the Russian retreat. Belloc claims the capture of Warsaw would be a great blow, but from studying the railroad facilities that would be left I cannot see where the enemy would find himself in any better position, save that the city would allow quarters for a great number of troops. So long as they keep their troops over there well and good. It will give us more time to accumulate ammunition, and keep the Germans from making another drive. By Christmas the Dardanelles will be opened. By spring Russia’s new armies will be trained, supplied, and equipped with a compliment [sic] of artillery and weakened Germany can be crushed into a heap from which she can never straighten out. We French will be the ones that will administer the final touch, as is
fitting and proper, for France from the first to the last has fought the whole war. I’m glad to note that Americans are beginning to realize it. A letter I have just received is typical of those I have been getting of late. It goes on to say “We hear the British are holding but twenty five miles of front. Is that possible? If so it is disgusting. The more I think about it the more I am convinced that the French are the wonderful, noble, people of this war. They are so admirable; they do not prate about it, but even give most of the credit to others.” When you consider that the war has been going double shift now for about a year, lacking but a few days now, it is surprising that people in America are just waking up to the truth.. They’re a soulless bunch those Yankees anyway. Well I believe America will play a good part in the long run. Up until two months ago she was supplying on one twentieth of one percent of the ammunition used by the Allies. Now she is increasing a hundred percent on geometrical progression every month. ['We' lined through] They are taking ['our' lined through] their ordinance officers and putting them in charge of ['our' lined through] their ammunition usines. Ah that will be a sweet time when we have great quantities of shells to fire
with out ceasing. To hear the continuous sharp departs and the roll of dull roars as they boom off in the Boches trenches. As a crapoulland [sic] gunner said to me once “I tell you, you would laugh to see it. I shoot my torpille . She goes turning slowly over and over through the air and then drops right in the trench. Oh you see em [sic] go up. Legs and arms and heads. Rifles, helmets and sacks. All go up at once. Once I saw a whole Boche go up. Perfectly good Boche. Only one leg missing. He went up. Way up thirty meters." Yes, and I would laugh, damn em [sic], and the more mangled they are the better I’d like it. I would take keen delight in a string of German ears. They cut the throats of some of our comrades the other day and stuck their heads up over the trench on bayonets. Les salauds.

closer.salute: Well, good night and keep well, and don’t flirt.
closer.seg: You can leave off “Conducteur” on the address. It takes up room and serves no purpose, for there’s only one man with my name in Secteur Postal 84 and American Section.
